BY KEVIL DUHON
The Little Theater is back in
business this semester, after a
shortage of office space
threatened to change Levering

thinks will satisfy all parties
concern ."At least, we haven't
had anybody complaining yet,"
Schmith commented.
The plan leaves the second
floor as it was, with the Little
Theater reserved for alternate use
as a conference room when other
conference rooms are full.
Groups presently using the
second floor include the tutoring
committee, Chester's Place, the
Student Council, Bob Arellano's
playwriting classes, a recently
formed music co-op, and the
Writing Seminars' poetry and
prose readings.
The G.R.O. also stays where it
is, in one corner of the Student
Activities Commission office. A
new room, however, has been
built in an adjacent corner of the
office to accomodate the Spring
Fair committee and the
Eisenhower Symposium. The
Chaplain's Office donated an
office in Merryman Hall for the
Women's Center. "Our

philosophy was that students
should accomodate students,"
explained Schmith. "Everybody
gave a little...It was a community
effort."
The suggestion to divert the
second floor to office space was
first advanced in a survey made
by Director of Student Activities
Chris Colombo in order to find
space for the previously
mentioned groups--especially for
the Spring Fair committee, which
is already gearing up for Hopkins'
annual carnival. Protest was loud
and immediate. A petition
circulated by the groups involved
picked up approximately 700
signatures in three days.
David Fishkin, who heads the
Chaplain's Tutoring office, was a
leader in the protest. "We made
it very clear to Colonel Schmith
that we needed the space," said
Fishkin. "It (Chester's Place) has
become a tradition. It's the only
small theater on campus, and
combined with the muraled
room, there's no other place like
it."
When asked about the
petition, Schmith said, "The
signatures didn't matter. We
talked to Bob Arellano and
Chaplain Wickwire. We asked the
Union Board and Student
Council for recommendations.
Everybody said to keep the Little
Theater. Of course we took that
into consideration, but we also
wanted the most efficient use of
space and monies. The new office
down there is infinitely cheaper
than renovation upstairs. Their
own room also gives security to
M.S.E. and the Spring Fair."

Good Job Umran
Umran liras started out a little over two years ago as a
secretary in the Housing Office. Within the space of a year,
she became administrative assistant, acting and then
permanent Housings Director. Certainly, her rise was
occasioned more by good fortune than by any 'outstanding
brilliance she displayed. But this in no way detracts from
the record .she compiled during her tenure. All in all, she
performed very creditably.
Chief among the innovations for which she was
responsible is the new housing lottery through which all
spaces were made available to both undergraduate and
graduate students. This system, worked so well that in
several categories of apartment spaces every student who
entered the lottery eventually received an option on some
type of University accomodation. The new method is much
fairer than the old way when graduate students were given a
preference and undergraduates could only slip in through
the back door.
The recent departures of Umran and of Martha Grimm
have left a noticeable vacuum. Her temporarysuccessor, in a
part-time role, will doubtless do her best, but a full-time
Director is needed. The University in the past has placed
pitifully little emphasis on the directorship within its
bureaucratic hierarchy. But it is a position which directly
affects a large number of students, and a serious effort
should be made to replace Uras as soon as possible.

No Clean Sweep

over the treatment received by the janitorial staff in the
Department of Housekeeping, Richard Zdanis and the
administration have in effect washed their hands of the
matter.
They are still far from clean, however. The janitors
remain u-nhappy, and the student unrest continues,.
sharpened by the tactic the administration adopted of
letting the matter die over the semester break. Its repeated
refusal to meet with concerned students and union leaders
at one time is further evidence of a lack of good faith in
resolving the problem.
The Office of Plant Planning has done its best to sweep
the _janitors and their grievances under the rug. But before
the matter is settled, they may yet be able to escape into

Good Job Umran
Umran liras started out a little over two years ago as a
secretary in the Housing Office. Within the space of a year,
she became administrative assistant, acting and then
permanent Housings Director. Certainly, her rise was
occasioned more by good fortune than by any 'outstanding
brilliance she displayed. But this in no way detracts from
the record .she compiled during her tenure. All in all, she
performed very creditably.
Chief among the innovations for which she was
responsible is the new housing lottery through which all
spaces were made available to both undergraduate and
graduate students. This system, worked so well that in
several categories of apartment spaces every student who
entered the lottery eventually received an option on some
type of University accomodation. The new method is much
fairer than the old way when graduate students were given a
preference and undergraduates could only slip in through
the back door.
The recent departures of Umran and of Martha Grimm
have left a noticeable vacuum. Her temporarysuccessor, in a
part-time role, will doubtless do her best, but a full-time
Director is needed. The University in the past has placed
pitifully little emphasis on the directorship within its
bureaucratic hierarchy. But it is a position which directly
affects a large number of students, and a serious effort
should be made to replace Uras as soon as possible.
